repnme.cdata!: Bosnia and Herzegovina - Emergency Recovery Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This project's overall outcome is
            rated as satisfactory. While there were differences among
            and within components, overall achievement of objectives was
            substantial, and most components are likely to be sustained.
            Overall performance by the International Development
            Association (IDA) was highly satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was satisfactory in all aspects of physical
            implementation. However, because of ethnic distrust and the
            country's complex political structure, consensus was
            difficult to achieve, which sometimes impeded progress. A
            key reason for the project's success was the strong and
            well-functioning project coordination unit, which exercised
            effective control over the various subcomponents. Other
            lessons learned are: Developing a parallel reform program
            can lay the groundwork for long-term sustainability of
            government investments beyond reconstruction. IDA can
            effectively leverage its activities by pursuing pilot
            projects and by paying early, consistent attention to
            cofinancing possibilities. An adequate amount of
            well-targeted, high-quality technical assistance is key to
            realize emergency project objectives. Establishment of
            monitoring and auditing agencies and systems increases
            project effectiveness and accountability. At the outset of
            the project, the project executing agency should be
            established and its director appointed and involved in
            project design and negotiations. IDA backstopping on the
            ground and intensive project supervision are needed.
